EQUIPMENT.NAME: 6 Gal AG
EQUIPMENT.NOTES: 10 Gal. Pot with 10 Gal. Igloo Mash Tun

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Honey
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Can be used to lighten flavor and body when substituted for malt. Generally limit to 30% when used as an adjunct. Pasturize and add to primary during fermentation. Use up to 100% for meads.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Acid Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Acid malt contains acids from natural lactic acids. Used by German brewers to adjust malt PH without chemicals to adhere to German purity laws. Also enhances the head retention.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Amber Dry Extract
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Amber colored dry malt extract, for general purpose use. Use in any medium to dark colored beer. Examples: Ales, Marzens, Amber Ale, India Pale Ale

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Amber Liquid Extract
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Unhopped amber color liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any Ale. Examples: Amber ale, India Pale Ale, Munich style, Marzen, Bock

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Amber Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Roasted specialty malt used in some English browns, milds and old ales to add color and a biscuit taste. Intense flavor - so limit use. Low diastatic power so must be mashed with well modified malts.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: American 2 Row
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Base malt for all beer styles

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Aromatic Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Provides a very strong malt flavor and aroma to your beer.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Barley Hulls
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Hulls are introduced to improve the speed of lautering when making high gravity or high adjunct beers. Hulls are neutral in flavor, body and color, and are inert Good for wheat beers, Wits, and others that have high protein mashes.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Barley, Flaked
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds significant body to Porters and Stouts. High haze producing protein prevents use in light beers.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Barley, Raw
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Raw, unmalted barley can be used to add body to your beer. Use in homebrew requires very fine milling combined with a decoction or multi-stage mash. Performs best when used in small quantities with well modified grains.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Barley, Torrefied
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Raw barley that has been "popped" open to open kernels Used in place of raw barley for faster conversion and higher yields. High in haze producing protein

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Biscuit Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Use for English ales, brown ales and porters. Adds a biscuit like flavor and aroma. Can be used as a substitute for toasted malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Black (Patent) Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Dark color and dry roasted flavor characteristic of Stouts and Porters Use for: Coloring in small amounts, or flavoring of Stouts and Porters in larger amounts.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Black Barley (Stout)
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Unmalted barley roasted at high temperature to create a dry, coffee like flavor. Imparts a sharp acrid flavor characteristic of dry stouts. Gives "dryness" to a stout or porter -- much more so than regular Roasted Barley

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Brown Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Imparts a dry, biscuit flavor. Used in nut brown ales, porters and some Belgian ales.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Brown Sugar, Dark
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Imparts a rich sweet flavor. Used in Scottish ales, holiday ales and some old ales.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Brown Sugar, Light
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Imparts a rich sweet flavor. Used in Scottish ales, holiday ales and some old ales.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Candi Sugar, Amber, Liquid
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer. Darker variants also add color.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Candi Sugar, Dark, Liquid
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Crystalized Candi Sugar (Sucrose) used in many Belgian Tripels, Dubbels, and holiday ales. Adds head retention and sweet aroma to beer. Darker variants also add color.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Cane (Beet) Sugar
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Common household baking sugar. Lightens flavor and body of beer. Can contribute a cider-like flavor to the beer if not cold-fermented or used in large quantities.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Cara-Pils/Dextrine
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Significantly increases foam/head retention and body of the beer. Also sold under the names "Dextrine" and "Cara-Foam"

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Carafa I
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Used to intensify aroma and color in dark, Munich beers and stouts.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Carafa II
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Used to intensify aroma and color in dark, Munich beers and stouts.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Carafa III
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Dark color and aroma - used in some German beers

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Carafoam
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Significantly increases foam/head retention and body of the beer. Also sold under the names "Dextrine" and "Cara-Pils (TM)"

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel Wheat Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Caramel wheat malt - emphasizes wheat malt aroma and adds color to the beer. Popular for Dunkelweizens. Also known as Carawheat -- which is a registered trademark of Wyermann Malting.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 10L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 15L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 20L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 30L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 40L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 60L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 80L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt -120L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt. Very Dark

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramunich Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Caramel, copper colored malt. Used in Belgian ales and German bocks.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Carared
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caravienne Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Light Belgian crystal malt. Used in light Trappist and Abbey style Belgian ales.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Chocolate Rye Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Primarily used for color and aroma in top-fermented specialty beers.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Corn Sugar (Dextrose)
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Widely used for bottling at rate of approx 2/3 cup per 5 gallons of beer

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Corn Syrup
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Syrup derived from corn with many of the same properties as corn sugar. May be used to enhance gravity without adding much body or flavor. Limit percentage in batch to avoid wine/cider flavors.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Corn, Flaked
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Generally a neutral flavor, used to reduce maltiness of beer Produces beer with a milder, less malty flavor Uses: Primarily for light Bohemian and Pilsner lagers

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Dark Dry Extract
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Dark dry extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any dark ale or lager.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Dark Liquid Extract
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Unhopped dark liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any dark beer. Examples: Porter, Brown ale, Bock, Oktoberfest, Stouts

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Extra Light Dry Extract
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Very light color dry malt extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any ale or lager.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Honey Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Intensely sweet - adds a sweet malty flavor sometimes associated with honey. Also called Brumalt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Light Dry Extract
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Pale dry malt extract for general purpose use. Use as base or to increase gravity of any full bodied ale or lager.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Lyle's Golden Syrup
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Liquid Invert Sugar. Used to increase alcohol and lighten the beer without alterning flavor. Used in Belgian ales and some English ales.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Maple Syrup
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: If added during the boil it will add a dry, woodsy flavor. If added at bottling, the smooth maple flavor comes through. Used for maple ales, porters, browns.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Melanoiden Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Aromatic malt from Banberg, Germany. Promotes a full flavor and rounds off beer color. Promotes deep red color and malty flavor.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Mild Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Also called "English Mild" - a light specialty malt used in Brown Ales

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Milk Sugar (Lactose)
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Not fully fermentable, so it adds lasting sweetness. Lactose can be added to lend sweetness to Sweet Stouts and Porters.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Molasses
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Imparts a strong, sweet flavor. Used primarily in stouts and porters.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Munich Malt - 10L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a slight orange color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Munich Malt - 20L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a orange to deep orange color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Oats, Flaked
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, mouth feel and head retention to the beer Used in oatmeal stouts and porters Adds substantial protein haze to light beers Protein rest recommended unless flakes are pregelatinized

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Oats, Malted
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Malted oats. Adds body, mouth feel and head retention to the beer Creates chill haze in lighter beers, so is primarily used in dark ones.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Chocolate Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Liquid Extract
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Unhopped pale liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any ale or lager.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Malt (2 Row) Bel
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Base malt for all beer styles Higher potential yield than US, English equivalent pale ale malts

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Malt (2 Row) UK
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Base malt for all English beer styles Lower diastatic power than American 2 Row Pale Malt

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Malt (2 Row) US
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Base malt for all beer styles

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Malt, Maris Otter
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Premium base malt from the UK. Popular for many English styles of beer including ales, pale ales and bitters.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Peat Smoked Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Robust smoky malt that provides a smoky flavor. Used in scottish ales and wee heavy ales.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pilsner (2 Row) Bel
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Belgian base malt for Continental lagers

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pilsner (2 Row) Ger
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: German base for Pilsners and Bohemian Lagers

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pilsner (2 Row) UK
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Pilsner base malt

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pilsner Liquid Extract
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Unhopped pale liquid extract. Use as a base malt for any ale or lager.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Rice Extract Syrup
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Used like other rice adjuncts in American and Japenes lagers to provide a dry, clean taste and light body. Adds gravity without changing body or flavor substantially. Use in place of corn sugar in small quantities.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Rice Hulls
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Hulls are introduced to improve the speed of lautering when making high gravity or high adjunct beers. Hulls are neutral in flavor, body and color, and are inert Good for wheat beers, Wits, and others that have high protein mashes.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Rice, Flaked
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Used to add fermentables without increasing body or flavor. Produces a milder, less grainy tasting beer. Examples: American lagers, Bohemian lagers, Pilsners

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Roasted Barley
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Roasted at high temperature to create a burnt, grainy, coffee like flavor. Imparts a red to deep brown color to beer, and very strong roasted flavor. Use 2-4% in Brown ales to add a nutty flavor, or 3-10% in Porters and Stouts for coffee flavor.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Rye Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds a dry, crisp character to the beer. Yields a deep red color, and a distinctive rye flavor Must limit to 10-15% fo the mash as it tends to produce "stuck" mashes.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Rye, Flaked
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Imparts a dry, crisp rye flavor to rye beers. Can be easier to mash than raw rye.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Smoked Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Malt that has been smoked over an open fire. Creates a distinctive "smoked" flavor and aroma. Used primarily for German Rauchbier but can also be added to Brown Ales and Porters.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Special B Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Extreme caramel aroma and flavored malt. Used in dark Belgian Abbey and Trappist ales. Unique flavor and aroma.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Special Roast
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Use for English ales, nut brown ales and porters. Adds a toasted, biscuit like flavor and aroma

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Sugar, Table (Sucrose)
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: White table sugar, or sucrose primarily is used to increase alcohol. Using too much will add a cider flavor to beer.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Toasted Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Toasted malt can be made at home by toasting pale malted barley for 10-15 minutes at 350 F. Similar to Biscuit or Victory malt - this malt adds reddish/orange color and improved body without sweetness. Toasted flavor. Mashing required to avoid haze.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Turbinado
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Light, raw brown sugar. May be used in British pale ales or high gravity Belgian ales. Limit percentage used to avoid undesirable flavors. Similar to Demerara sugar.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Victory Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Toasted malt that adds a "Biscuit" or toasted flavor to English ales. Use for: Nut brown ales, porters

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Vienna Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Kiln dried malt darker than Pale Malt, but not as dark as Munich Malt Imparts a golden to orange color to the beer.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Wheat Dry Extract
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Wheat based dry extract for use in all wheat beers. Use as base or to increase gravity of any wheat beer. Examples: Weizen, weiss, wheat ales and lagers

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Wheat Liquid Extract
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Unhopped Wheat liquid malt extract. Contains approx 60% Wheat, 40% Barley Use for Bavarian wheats, weizens, weiss and dunkel weizen styles.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Wheat Malt, Bel
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Malted wheat for use in Wheat beers

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Wheat Malt, Dark
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Dark malted wheat base for use in dark wheat styles such as Dunkleweizen.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Wheat Malt, Ger
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Malted wheat base for use in all wheat styles

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Wheat, Flaked
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Flaked wheat adds to increased body and foam retention Used in place of raw or torrified wheat for faster conversion and better yield. May be used in small amounts to improve head retention and body Examples: Belgian White beer, Wit

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Wheat, Roasted
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Also called Chocolate Wheat Malt. Kilned raw wheat - adds a deep, dark brown color to dunkelweizens and other dark beer styles. Roasted, woody, charcoal or burnt toast flavor depending on degree of roasting.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Wheat, Torrified
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Unmodified wheat that has been "popped" to open the kernels Used primarily in place of raw wheat when making Belgian White and Wit Faster conversion and higher yield than raw wheat Protein rest recommended when mashing

FERMENTABLE.NAME: White Wheat Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: White wheat gives a malty flavor not available from raw wheat. Used in Weiss, Wit and White beers

HOP.NAME: Cascade
HOP.NOTES: Use For: American ales and lagers Aroma: Strong spicy, floral, grapefriut character Substitutes: Centennial Examples: Sierra Nevade Pale Ale, Anchor Liberty Ale A hops with Northern Brewers Heritage

HOP.NAME: Centennial
HOP.NOTES: Use for: General purpose bittering, aroma in American ales and Wheats Aroma: Floral, citrus aroma, spicy, clean bittering flavor Substitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion Examples: Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale, Sierra Nevada Bigfoot

HOP.NAME: Chinook
HOP.NOTES: Use for: Strong versitile bittering hop for ales, porters, stouts Aroma: Heavy and spicy aroma Substitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion Examples: Sierra Nevada Stout, Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale

HOP.NAME: Columbia
HOP.NOTES: Sibling of Williamette hops. Used for: All English Ales Aroma: Close to fuggles Substitutes: Fuggles, Williamette

HOP.NAME: Fuggles
HOP.NOTES: Used For: General purpose bittering/aroma for English Ales, Dark Lagers Aroma: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aroma Substitute: East Kent Goldings, Williamette Examples: Samuel Smith's Pale Ale, Old Peculiar, Thomas Hardy's Ale

HOP.NAME: Goldings, East Kent
HOP.NOTES: Used For: General purpose hops for bittering/finishing all British Ales Aroma: Floral, aromatic, earthy, slightly sweet spicy flavor Substitutes: Fuggles, BC Goldings Examples: Bass Pale Ale, Fullers ESB, Samual Smith's Pale Ale

HOP.NAME: Hallertauer Hersbrucker
HOP.NOTES: Use for: German style lagers and wheat beers Aroma: Noble, pleasant, clean flavor Substitutes: Mt. Hood, Liberty, Hallertauer, Mittelfrueh Examples: Wheathook Wheaten Ale

HOP.NAME: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh
HOP.NOTES: Used for: Continental Lagers, German Ales/Lagers, US Lagers Aroma: Pleasant, assertive, mild herbal aroma Substitutes: Hallertauer, Mt. Hood, Liberty, Crystal Examples: Sam Adams Boston Lager, Sam Adams Boston Lightship

HOP.NAME: Horizon
HOP.NOTES: Good dual purpose hops derived from Nugget hops in Oregon (1970) Use for: All purpose Ales, Lagers Aroma: Pleasant, Hoppy Substitutions: Magnum or other high alpha hops

HOP.NAME: Liberty
HOP.NOTES: Use for: German style lagers Aroma: Fine, mild, slightly spicy flavor Substitutes: Hallertau, Mt hood, Crystal Examples: Pete's Wicked Lager

HOP.NAME: Northern Brewer
HOP.NOTES: Also called Hallertauer Northern Brewers Use for: Bittering and finishing both ales and lagers of all kinds Aroma: Fine, dry, clean bittering hop. Unique flavor. Substitute: Hallertauer Mittelfrueh, Hallertauer Examples: Anchor Steam, Old Peculiar,

HOP.NAME: Simcoe
HOP.NOTES: High alpha bitterng hops with good aroma characteristics. Citrus aroma. Best for: IPAs Substitutes: N/A

HOP.NAME: Styrian Goldings
HOP.NOTES: A seedless version of Fuggles grown in Slovenia Use for: Bittering, finishing for a wide variety of European Beers. Popular in Europe and the United Kingdom Aroma: Similar to Fuggles: Mild, soft, grassy, floral aroma Substitutes: Fuggles Williamet

HOP.NAME: Tettnang
HOP.NOTES: Use for: German ales, lagers and wheat beer Aroma: Noble, mild, fine, slightly spicy Substitutes: Saaz, Spalt Examples: Sam Adams Octoberfest, Anderson Valley ESB

HOP.NAME: Warrior
HOP.NOTES: High alpha hops from Yakima Chief Ranches. Also called YCR-5. Best for: Ales, Stouts Substitutes: Nugget

HOP.NAME: Williamette
HOP.NOTES: Use for: Finishing American and British Ales Aroma: Mild, grassy, floral, slightly spicy Substitutes: Fuggles, E.K. Goldings Examples: Sierra Nevada Porter, Ballard Bitter

MASH.NAME: Decoction Mash, Double
MASH.NOTES: Used for some authentic German styles. Attempt to draw decoction from the thickest portion of the mash. Profiles vary. Some traditional German mashes use a long acid rest at 40 deg C. Also some sources recommend the decoction amount be given a 15 minute saccharification rest at 158 F (70 C) before boiling it.

MASH_STEP.NAME: Protein Rest
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 5.00 gal of water at 126.6 F

MASH_STEP.NAME: Saccharification
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Decoct 1.61 gal of mash and boil it

MASH_STEP.NAME: Saccharification
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Decoct 0.98 gal of mash and boil it

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash Out
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Heat to 168.0 F over 10 min

MASH.NAME: Double Infusion
MASH.NOTES: Double step infusion - for medium body beers requiring a protein rest. Used primarily in beers high in unmodified grains or adjuncts.

MASH_STEP.NAME: Protein Rest
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 2.25 gal of water at 132.1 F

MASH_STEP.NAME: Saccrification
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 2.00 gal of water at 197.3 F

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash Out
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 1.75 gal of water at 205.6 F

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash In
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 3.10 gal of water at 166.0 F

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash Out
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 1.90 gal of water at 194.2 F

MASH.NAME: Single Infusion, Batch Sparge
MASH.NOTES: Simple single infusion mash for use with most modern well modified grains (about 95% of the time).

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash In
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 3.13 gal of water at 165.9 F

MASH.NAME: Single Infusion, Full Body
MASH.NOTES: Simple single infusion mash for use with most modern well modified grains (about 95% of the time).

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash In
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 3.13 gal of water at 170.5 F

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash Out
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 1.25 gal of water at 196.6 F

MASH.NAME: Single Infusion, No Mash Out
MASH.NOTES: Simple single infusion mash for use with most modern well modified grains (about 95% of the time).

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash In
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 3.13 gal of water at 165.9 F

YEAST.NAME: American Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Soft, smooth, clean finish. Very well balanced. Very versitile -- works well with many ale styles.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: American Pale Ale, Scottish Ale, Porters, Sweet Stout, Barley Wine, Alt

YEAST.NAME: American Ale II
YEAST.NOTES: Clean, tart, nutty flavor. More fruity than Wyeast American Ale yeast.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: All American Ales, Brown Ales, Barley Wine

YEAST.NAME: American Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Bold, with a complex aroma. Good flavor depth characteristics for a wide variety of lager beers.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: American Lagers and Pilsners

YEAST.NAME: American Wheat Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Dry, Crisp, tart beer in the American Hefeweizen style. Low flocculation aids in producing desired chill haze.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: American Wheat, Berlin Weiss, Hefeweizen

YEAST.NAME: Bavarian Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Use by many German breweries. Produces a full-bodied, rich, malty beer.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: German Bocks, Vienna, Oktoberfest, Hells, Marzens, Dunkel

YEAST.NAME: Bavarian Wheat
YEAST.NOTES: Hefeweizen yeast with complex flavor and aroma. Bubble gum, banana flavors with apple/plub ester profile. Malty flavor.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bavarian Weizen, Hefeweizen

YEAST.NAME: Bavarian Wheat Yeast
YEAST.NOTES: Blend of top-fermenting ale and wheat yeasts providing a mild ester and phenolic profile.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bavarian style wheat beers.

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Abbey II
YEAST.NOTES: Dry flavor with slight fruitiness. High alcohol tolerance.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Ales, Trappist Ales, Abbey Ales, Grand Cru

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Trappist style ale yeast. Complex estery flavor.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Ales, Abbey Ales, Trappist Ales

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Ardennes
YEAST.NOTES: Phenolics develop at increased temperature. Mild fruitiness and complex spicy flavor.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Ale

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Lambic Blend
YEAST.NOTES: Lambic culture of Saccharomyces Cerevisiar and a mixture of yeasts and bacterias. Blend of organisms helps create lactic flavor of Belgian Lambics.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Lambic

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Saison
YEAST.NOTES: Classic farmhouse ale yeast. Spicy, complex aromatics including bubble gum. Tart and dry on the palate with mild fruitiness. Finishes crisp and mildly acidic. Ferment at warm temperature. May have vigorous fermentation start.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Saison beer

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Strong Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Dry, tart, fruity flavor. High alcohol tolerance.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Ales, Scottish Strong Ale,Trappist Ales, Dubbels, Trippels

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Wheat Yeast
YEAST.NOTES: Estery lor phenol yeast. Plum and apple aroma with a dry finish.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Wheat, Bavarian Weizen

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Witbier
YEAST.NOTES: Tart, slightly phenolic character. For Wits and Grand Cru. Tolerates high gravity beers well.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Wit, Grand Cru

YEAST.NAME: Bohemian Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Ferments clean and malty, with rich malty flavor for full gravity pilsners.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bohemian Pilsners, Pilsners, German Helles, Bocks

YEAST.NAME: Brettanomyces Bruxellensis
YEAST.NOTES: Wild yeast strain isolated from Brussels region of Belgium. Adds classic sweaty horse hair flavor as well as sourness and cherry-pie like flavor. Generally used in conjunction with S. Cerevisiae after the primary fermentation has begun. Requires 3-6 mo
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Lambic, Gueze Lambic, and Sour Browns

YEAST.NAME: British Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Fruity, tart, dry crisp finish. Very well balanced.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: All British Ales, Pales, Bitters, English Strong Ale

YEAST.NAME: British Ale II
YEAST.NOTES: Malty, clean, crisp finish. Dry flavor.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: British and Canadian Ales, English Bitters

YEAST.NAME: British Cask Ale
YEAST.NOTES: A great choice for any cask conditioned British Ale. Produces nice malt profile with a hint of fruit. Finishes dry and slightly tart.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: British Ales

YEAST.NAME: Budvar Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Classic pilsner lager yeast. Malty nose and subtle fruit. Rich malt profile, but dry crisp finish. Hop character accentuated by dry finish.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bohemian Pilsner, Classic Pilsners, Dortmunder and Light Lagers

YEAST.NAME: California Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Suited for 19th century California style beers. Lagers at high temperature and produces malty, clear beers.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: California common beers, Steam Beer

YEAST.NAME: Czech Pilsner Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Classic Pilsner strain. Creates a dry but malty finish. Perfect for Pilsners and bocks. Some sulfur produced, but will fade with time.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bohemian and American Pilsner, Bocks, Oktoberfest, Marzen

YEAST.NAME: Danish Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Rich, Dortmund style, with a crisp, dry finish. Soft profile accentuates hop flavor.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Dortmund/Export Lagers

YEAST.NAME: European Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Very malty flavor characteristic of Bavarian/Munich Ales. Complex character.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: European Ales, German Ales, Alts, Pale Ale, Brown Ale, Kolsch

YEAST.NAME: European Lager II
YEAST.NOTES: Clean, dry flavor profile for aggressively hopped pilsners. Dry finish, mild aroma, slight sulfur production.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bohemian Pilsner, American Pilsner, Helles, Dunkel

YEAST.NAME: Forbidden Fruit
YEAST.NOTES: Phenolic profile with subdued fruitiness. Available seasonally.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Wit, Grand Cru

YEAST.NAME: GF All American Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Popular all purpose American ale style now in a Gluten Free strain. Produces beers that are nutty, clean with a slight tart finish. Ferment warmer to accentuate hops and add fruitiness or ferment cold for clean light citrus character.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: American Amber, Brown, IPA, Pale ales and stouts. Blondes and fruit beers.

YEAST.NAME: German Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Crisp, dry finish with a mild flavor.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: German Ales, Alts, Kolsch, Dry Stout

YEAST.NAME: German Wheat
YEAST.NOTES: Subtle flavor profile. Sharp, fruity, crisp, sherry like flavor.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bavarian Weizen

YEAST.NAME: Irish Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Dry diacetyl, fruity flavor characteristic of stouts. Full bodied, dry, clean flavor.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Irish Dry Stouts, Porter, Scottish Ale, Brown Ale, Imperial Stout, Barley Wine

YEAST.NAME: Kolsch Yeast
YEAST.NOTES: Very malty flavor with mix of lager and ale character. Crisp, clean finish.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Kolsch, European Ales

YEAST.NAME: Lactobacillus Delbrueckii
YEAST.NOTES: Lactic acid bacteria isolated from Belgium. Produces mild acidity and sourness found in many types of Belgian beers. Always used in conjunction with S. Cerevisiae and wild yeasts.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian gueze, lambic, sour brown ales, and Berliner Weisse.

YEAST.NAME: London Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Dry finish, bold, rich flavor, some fruit profile and a crisp finish.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: English Ales, Bitters, IPAs, Brown Ale

YEAST.NAME: London Ale III
YEAST.NOTES: Light, fruity flavor. Balanced flavor with hint of sweetness.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: British Ales, Bitters

YEAST.NAME: London ESB Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Malty, balanced flavor. Fruity, rich finish. Excellent for cask conditioned ales and bitters.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: English Bitters, IPA, Brown Ales, Mild Ales

YEAST.NAME: Munich Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Unique Pilsner strain. Very smooth, well-rounded and full bodied. Benefits from a diacetyl rest.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Pilsners, Light Lagers, Dortmond/Export, Marzen/Oktoberfest, Dunkel

YEAST.NAME: North American Lager
YEAST.NOTES: American and Canadian lager yeast. Malty finish makes it suitable for Marzens/Oktoberfest as well.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: American Pilsner, California Common, Canadian Lager, Oktoberfest, Marzen

YEAST.NAME: Northwest Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Classic Northwest US ale yeast. Slight fruit flavor, malty ale with good body and balance.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Oregon Ales, All American Ale styles

YEAST.NAME: Pediococcus Cerevisiae
YEAST.NOTES: Lactic acid bacteria isolated from Belgium. Creates a high level of lactic acidity over a long time. Often used with other yeasts, and it may take several months for flavor to fully develop.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Gueze and other Belgian styles.

YEAST.NAME: Pilsen Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Classic American pilsner strain. Smooth with a malty flavor. Dry and crisp fermentation.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: American Pilsner, Bohemian Pilsner, Light Lagers

YEAST.NAME: Ringwood Ale
YEAST.NOTES: European ale yeast. Highly flocculant with complex, clear, but malty profile. Slightly fruity ester.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Ringwood Ale, Brown Ales

YEAST.NAME: Roselare Belgian Blend
YEAST.NOTES: Culture of Saccharomyces, Brettonomyces and Lactic Acid Bacteria. Complex aromas and flavors. May be used for primary fermentation. Primarily for sour brown and red Belgian styles.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian sour brown and red beers.

YEAST.NAME: Scottish Ale
YEAST.NOTES: High alcohol tolerance.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Scottish Ale, Scottish Strong Ales, Sweet Stout, Imperial Stout, Barley Wine

YEAST.NAME: Thames Valley Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Clean, complex flavor. Low in fruit, low in esters, rich in flavor. Hops come through well.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: British Bitters, ESB, India Pale Ale, English Strong Ale

YEAST.NAME: Trappist High Gravity
YEAST.NOTES: Robust top cropping yeast. Phenolic character and alcohol tolerance up to 12%. Rich ester profile and malty flavor.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Wit, Trappist Ale, High gravity ales

YEAST.NAME: Urquell Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Pilsner Urquell yeast with mild fruit/floral aroma. Very dry and clean on palate with full mouth feel. Subtle malt character. Clean and neutral finish.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bohemian Pilsner

YEAST.NAME: Weihenstephan Weizen
YEAST.NOTES: Unique Bavarian wheat yeast that produces the spicy weizen clove and banana flavor. Best when fermented at around 68 deg F.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bavarian Weizen

YEAST.NAME: Whitbread Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Slightly more fruity and malty than Wyeast's British Ale. Clear and highly flocculant.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Whitbread Ale, British Ales, Pales, Bitters

YEAST.NAME: Wyeast Ale Blend
YEAST.NOTES: Blend of ale strains designed to provide quick starts, good flavor, balance and flocculation. Balanced finish suitable for most American and British ale styles.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: American and British Ale Styles.

YEAST.NAME: Wyeast Lager Blend
YEAST.NOTES: Blend of lager strains to produce a complex but clean lager flavor profile. Suitable for many common lager styles.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Classic Pilsners, Lagers, Bocks.

YEAST.NAME: Abbey Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Used in two of six remaining Trappist breweries. Distinctive plum and fruitiness. Good for high gravity beers.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Trappist Ale, Spiced Ale, Trippel, Dubbel, Grand Cru

YEAST.NAME: American Hefeweizen Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Produces a much smaller amount of clove and banana flavor than the German Hefeweizen White Labs yeast. Some sulfur, and creates desired cloudy look.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Oregon style American Hefeweizen

YEAST.NAME: American Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Dry and clean with very slight apple fruitiness. Minimal sulfer and diacetyl.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: All American Style Lagers -- both light and dark.

YEAST.NAME: Australian Ale Yeast
YEAST.NOTES: White Labs entry for Australian Ales. Produces a clean, malty finish with pleasant ester character. Bready character. Can ferment clean at high temperatures.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Australian Ales, English Ales

YEAST.NAME: Bastogne Belgian Ale
YEAST.NOTES: High gravity Trappist ale yeast. Creates a dry beer with a slightly acidic finish. Cleaner finish and slightly less spicy than WLP500 or WLP530.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: High gravity beers, Belgian ales, Dubbels, Trippels.

YEAST.NAME: Bavarian Weizen Yeast
YEAST.NOTES: Former yeast lab W51 strain. Produces a classic German style wheat beer with moderately high, spicy, phenolic overtones reminiscent of cloves.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bavarian Weizen and wheat beers.

YEAST.NAME: Bedford British Ale
YEAST.NOTES: High attenuation. Ferments dry with high flocculation. Distinctive ester profile. Good for most English ale styles.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: English style ales - bitter, pale, porter and brown ale

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Phenolic and spicy flavors. Complex profile, with less fruitiness than White's Trappist Ale strain.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Ales, Saisons, Belgian Reds, Belgian Browns, White beers

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Golden Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Combination of fruitiness and phenolic characters dominate the profile. Some sulfur which will dissapate following fermentation.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Ales, Dubbel, Grand Cru, Belgian Holiday Ale

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Saison I Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Saison yeast from Wallonia. Earthy, spicy and peppery notes. Slightly sweet.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Saison Ale, Belgian Ale, Dubbel, Trippel

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Style Ale Yeast Blend
YEAST.NOTES: Blend of two trappist ale yeasts and one Belgian ale yeast. Creates a versatile blend to be used for Trappist and other Belgian style ales.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Trappist and other Belgian ales.

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Wit Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Phenolic and tart. The original yeast used to produce Wit in Belgium.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Wit

YEAST.NAME: Belgian Wit II
YEAST.NOTES: Less phenolic than WLP400 (Belgian Wit Ale) but more spicy. Leaves a little more sweetness and flocculation is higher than WLP400.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Belgian Wit, Spiced Ale, Wheat Ales and Specialty Beers

YEAST.NAME: British Ale
YEAST.NOTES: This yeast has higher attenuation than the White Labs English Ale yeast strains. Produces a malty flavored beer.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Excellent for all English style ales including bitters, pale ale, porters and brown ale.

YEAST.NAME: Burton Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Burton-on-trent yeast produces a complex character. Flavors include apple, pear, and clover honey.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: All English styles including Pale Ale, IPA, Porter, Stout and Bitters.

YEAST.NAME: California Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Very clean flavor, balance and stability. Accentuates hop flavor Versitile - can be used to make any style ale.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: American Style Ales, Ambers, Pale Ales, Brown Ale, Strong Ale

YEAST.NAME: California Ale V
YEAST.NOTES: Similar to White Labs California Ale Yeast, but slightly lower attenuation leaves a fuller bodied beer.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: American style Pales, Ambers, Browns, IPAs, American Strong Ale

YEAST.NAME: Champagne Yeast
YEAST.NOTES: Can tolerate alcohol up to 17%. For Barley Wine or Meads.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Wine, Mead and Cider

YEAST.NAME: Cry Havoc
YEAST.NOTES: Licensed by White Labs from Charlie Papazian, author of "The Complete Joy of Home Brewing". This yeast was used to brew many of his original recipes. Diverse strain can ferment at ale and lager temps.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: All American Style Lagers -- both light and dark.

YEAST.NAME: Czech Budejovice Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Dry and crisp with low diacetyl production. From Southern Czech Republic.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bohemian Style Pilsner

YEAST.NAME: Dry English Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Clean, Highly flocculant, and highly attentive yeast. Similar to White labs English Ale yeast, but more attentive. Suitable for high gravity ales.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Pale Ales, Amber, ESB, Brown Ales, Strong Ales

YEAST.NAME: Dusseldorf Alt Yeast
YEAST.NOTES: Traditional Alt yeast from Dusseldorf, Germany. Produces clean, slightly sweet alt beers. Does not accentuate hop flavor like WLP029 does.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Alt biers, Dusseldorf Alts, German Ales

YEAST.NAME: East Coast Ale
YEAST.NOTES: White labs "Brewer Patriot" strain can be used to reproduce many of the American versions of classic beer styles. Very clean with low esters.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: American Ales, Golden ales, Blonde Ale, Pale Ale and German Alt styles

YEAST.NAME: Edinburgh Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Malty strong ale yeast. Reproduces complex, malty, flavorful schottish ales. Hop character comes through well.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Strong Scottish style ales, ESB, Irish Reds

YEAST.NAME: English Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Classic ESB strain best for English style milds, bitters, porters and English style stouts. Leaves a clear beer with some residual sweetness.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: English Pale Ale, ESB, India Pale Ale, Brown Ale, Porter, Sweet Stouts and Strong Ales

YEAST.NAME: English Cider Yeast
YEAST.NOTES: Classic Cider yeast. Ferments dry, but retains apple flavor. Some sulfer produced during fermentation will fade with age.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Cider, Wine and High Gravity Beer

YEAST.NAME: Essex Ale Yeast
YEAST.NOTES: Flavorful British yeast with a drier finish than many ale yeasts. Bready and fruity in character. Well suited for top cropping (collecting). Does not flocculate as much as WLP005 or WLP002.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: British milds, pale ales, bitters, stouts.

YEAST.NAME: European Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Malty, Northern European ale yeast. Low ester production, low sulfer, gives a clean profile. Low attenuation contributes to malty taste.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Alt, Kolsch, malty English Ales, Fruit beers

YEAST.NAME: German Ale II
YEAST.NOTES: Strong sulfer component will reduce with aging. Clean flavor, but with more ester production than regular German Ale Yeast.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Kolsch, Alt and German Pale Ales

YEAST.NAME: German Ale/Kolsch
YEAST.NOTES: Great for light beers. Accentuates hop flavors. Slight sulfer flavor will fade with age and leave a clean, lager like ale.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Kolsch, Altbiers, Pale Ales, Blonde and Honey Ales

YEAST.NAME: German Bock Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Produces beer that has balanced malt and hop character. From Southern Bavaria.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bocks, Doppelbocks, Oktoberfest, Vienna, Helles, some American Pilsners

YEAST.NAME: German Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Very malty and clean. One of the world's most popular lager yeasts.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: German Marzen, Pilsner, Lagers, Oktoberfest beers.

YEAST.NAME: Hefeweizen Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Produces the banana and clove nose traditionally associated with German Wheat beers. Also produces desired cloudy look.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: German style wheat beers. Weiss, Weizen, Hefeweizen

YEAST.NAME: Hefeweizen IV Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Large clove and phenolic aroma, but with minimal banana flavor. Citrus and apricot notes. Crisp and drinkable, with some sulfur production.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: German style Hefeweizen

YEAST.NAME: Irish Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Excellent for Irish Stouts. Produces slight hint of diacetyl balanced by a light fruitiness and a slightly dry crispness.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Irish Ales, Stouts, Porters, Browns, Reds and Pale Ale

YEAST.NAME: Klassic Ale Yeast
YEAST.NOTES: Traditional English Ale style yeast. Produces ester character, and allows hop flavor through. Leaves a slightly sweet malt character in ales.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Bitters, milds, porters stouts and scottish ale styles.

YEAST.NAME: London Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Dry, malty ale yeast. Produces a complex, oak flavored ester character. Hop bitterness comes through well.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Classic British Pale Ales, Bitters and Stouts

YEAST.NAME: Mexican Lager
YEAST.NOTES: From Mexico City - produces a clean lager beer with a crisp finish. Good for mexican style beers.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Mexican style light and dark lagers.

YEAST.NAME: Nottingham Ale Yeast
YEAST.NOTES: British style of ale yeast with a very dry finish and high attenuation. Medium to low fruit and fusel alcohol production. Good top fermenting yeast for cropping.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: British ales, pale ales, ambers, porters and stouts.

YEAST.NAME: Octoberfest/Marzen Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Produces a malty, bock style beer. Does not finish as dry or as fast as White's German Lager yeast. Longer lagering or starter recommended.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Marzen, Oktoberfest, European Lagers, Bocks, Munich Helles

YEAST.NAME: Old Bavarian Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Southern Germany/Bavarian lager yeast. Finishes malty with a slight ester profile.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Oktoberfest, Marzen, Bock and Dark Lagers.

YEAST.NAME: Pacific Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Popular yeast from the Pacific Northwest. Leaves a clear and malty profile. More fruity than WLP002. Suitable for many English and American styles.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: English & American ales including milds, bitters, IPA, porters and English stouts.

YEAST.NAME: Pilsner Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Classic pilsner strain from Czech Republic. Dry with a malty finish.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: European Pilsners, Bohemian Pilsner

YEAST.NAME: Premium Bitter Ale
YEAST.NOTES: From Staffordshire England. Mild, but complex estery flavor. High attenuation - ferments strong and dry. Suitable for high gravity beers.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: All English ales including bitters, milds, ESB, Porter, Stout and Barley Wine

YEAST.NAME: San Francisco Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Produces "California Common" style beer.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: California and Premium Lagers, all American Lagers

YEAST.NAME: Southern German Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Malty finish and balanced aroma. Strong fermenter, slight sulfur and low diacetyl.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: German Pilsner, Helles, Oktoberfest, Marzen, Bocks

YEAST.NAME: Southwold Ale
YEAST.NOTES: From Suffolk county. Products complex fruity and citrus flavors. Slight sulfer production, but this will fade with ageing.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: British bitters and pale ales.

YEAST.NAME: Steinberg-Geisenheim Wine
YEAST.NOTES: German origin wine yeast. High fruit/ester production. Moderate fermentation characteristics and cold tolerant.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Riesling wines.

YEAST.NAME: Super High Gravity Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Ferments up to 25% alcohol content. Flavor may vary greatly depending on beer alcohol. English like esters at low gravity, but will become more wine-like as alcohol exceeds 16% ABV. Refer to White Labs web page for tips on fermenting high gravity ales.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Very high gravity beers and barley wine up to 25% alcohol.

YEAST.NAME: Sweet Mead/Wine
YEAST.NOTES: Lower attenuation than White Labs Champagne Yeast. Leaves some residual sweetness as well as fruity flavor. Alcohol concentration up to 15%.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Sweet Mead, Wine and Cider

YEAST.NAME: Sweet Mead/Wine
YEAST.NOTES: Lower attenuation than White Labs Champagne Yeast. Leaves some residual sweetness as well as fruity flavor. Alcohol concentration up to 15%.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Sweet Mead, Wine and Cider

YEAST.NAME: Trappist Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Distinctive fruitiness and plum characteristics. Excellent for high gravity beers.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Trappist Ale, Dubbel, Trippel, Belgian Ales

YEAST.NAME: Zurich Lager
YEAST.NOTES: Swiss style lager yeast. Sulfer and diacytl production is minimal. May be used for high gravity lagers with proper care.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Swiss style lager, and high gravity lagers (over 11% ABV)

YEAST.NAME: London
YEAST.NOTES: Produces a clean, well balanced ale. Medium attenuation preserves some beer complexity.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Well balanced British style ales.

YEAST.NAME: Manchester
YEAST.NOTES: Old english style ale yeast that produces a complex, woody, full bodied ale at warm temperature. Medium attenuation. Good dry yeast for many english styles.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Complex, full bodied Porters, Stouts, Ales.

YEAST.NAME: Nottingham
YEAST.NOTES: Dry strain is highly flocculant and has high attenuation. Produces relatively few fruity esters for a dry yeast. Can be fermented at low temperature to produce lager-style beers.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Good neutral ale yeast.

WATER.NAME: Denver, Colorado
WATER.NOTES: Denver Metro Area -- suburbs may vary.

WATER.NAME: Distilled Water
WATER.NOTES: Neutral water, may be used as a base for creating desired water profile.

HOP.NAME: Hallertauer
HOP.NOTES: Used for: German Ales, German/US/Canadian Lagers, Wheat Beers Aroma: Pleaseant, mild spicy flavor, clean, neutral flavor Substitutes: Crytsal, Liberty, Hallertauer Mittenfrueh

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Rice Hulls
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Hulls are introduced to improve the speed of lautering when making high gravity or high adjunct beers. Hulls are neutral in flavor, body and color, and are inert Good for wheat beers, Wits, and others that have high protein mashes.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Malt (2 Row) US
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Base malt for all beer styles

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Honey Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Intensely sweet - adds a sweet malty flavor sometimes associated with honey. Also called Brumalt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Rice, Flaked
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Used to add fermentables without increasing body or flavor. Produces a milder, less grainy tasting beer. Examples: American lagers, Bohemian lagers, Pilsners

YEAST.NAME: American Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Soft, smooth, clean finish. Very well balanced. Very versitile -- works well with many ale styles.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: American Pale Ale, Scottish Ale, Porters, Sweet Stout, Barley Wine, Alt

STYLE.NAME: Fruit Beer
STYLE.NOTES: http://www.bjcp.org/2008styles/style20.html#1a A harmonious marriage of fruit and beer. The key attributes of the underlying style will be different with the addition of fruit; do not expect the base beer to taste the same as the unadulterated version. Judge the beer based on the pleasantness and balance of the resulting combination.
STYLE.PROFILE: Varies by fruit flavor and base style. Generally sweet with low hop flavor and aroma to enhance fruit flavor. Balanced with fruit flavor and aroma. Color, aroma, and flavor vary. Balance is important.
STYLE.INGREDIENTS: Vary by base style. OG, FG, IBUs, SRM and ABV will vary depending on the underlying base beer, but the fruit will often be reflected in the color.
STYLE.EXAMPLES: : New Glarus Belgian Red and Raspberry Tart, Bell's Cherry Stout, Dogfish Head Aprihop, Great Divide Wild Raspberry Ale, Founders Rbus, Ebulum Elderberry Black Ale, Stiegl Radler, Weyerbacher Raspberry Imperial Stout, Abita Purple Haze, +++

EQUIPMENT.NAME: 6 Gal AG
EQUIPMENT.NOTES: 10 Gal. Pot with 10 Gal. Igloo Mash Tun

MASH.NAME: Single Infusion, Light Body
MASH.NOTES: Simple single infusion mash for use with most modern well modified grains (about 95% of the time).

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash In
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 3.41 gal of water at 163.8 F

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash Out
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 2.20 gal of water at 196.4 F

HOP.NAME: Galena
HOP.NOTES: Use for: General bittering hops for all beers Aroma: Strong, clean, balanced bittering Substitute: Eroica, Northern Brewer, Cluster, Chinook Examples: Catamount Porter

HOP.NAME: Cascade
HOP.NOTES: Use For: American ales and lagers Aroma: Strong spicy, floral, grapefriut character Substitutes: Centennial Examples: Sierra Nevade Pale Ale, Anchor Liberty Ale A hops with Northern Brewers Heritage

HOP.NAME: Tettnang
HOP.NOTES: Use for: German ales, lagers and wheat beer Aroma: Noble, mild, fine, slightly spicy Substitutes: Saaz, Spalt Examples: Sam Adams Octoberfest, Anderson Valley ESB

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Malt (2 Row) US
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Base malt for all beer styles

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Rye Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds a dry, crisp character to the beer. Yields a deep red color, and a distinctive rye flavor Must limit to 10-15% fo the mash as it tends to produce "stuck" mashes.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 80L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Cara-Pils/Dextrine
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Significantly increases foam/head retention and body of the beer. Also sold under the names "Dextrine" and "Cara-Foam"

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Chocolate Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Chocolate Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.

YEAST.NAME: Ringwood Ale
YEAST.NOTES: European ale yeast. Highly flocculant with complex, clear, but malty profile. Slightly fruity ester.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: Ringwood Ale, Brown Ales

STYLE.NAME: Robust Porter
STYLE.NOTES: http://www.bjcp.org/2008styles/style12.html#1b A substantial, malty dark ale with a complex&flavorful roasty character Stronger, hoppier &/or roastier porter designed as either historical throwback or American interpretation of style.Trad versions have a more subtle hop character(often English)modern versions may be considerably more aggressive.Both types are valid
STYLE.PROFILE: Rather broad style open to interpretation distinguished from Stout as lacking strong roasted barley character.It differs from brown porter in that black patent/roasted grain character is usually present, & it can be stronger in alc.Roast intensity&malt flavors can vary significantly.May/may not have strong hop char,&may/may not have significant ferm.by-products.
STYLE.INGREDIENTS: May have several malts,darkroasted malts&grains,often inc. black patent malt(chocolate malt&/or roasted barley may be used).Bittering,flavor&/or aroma hops freq UK/US.H2O w mod - high carbonate hardness typ.Ale yeast either clean US/characterful Eng var.
STYLE.EXAMPLES: Great Lakes Edmund Fitzgerald Porter, Meantime London Porter, Anchor Porter, Smuttynose Robust Porter, Sierra Nevada Porter, Deschutes Black Butte Porter, Boulevard Bully! Porter, Rogue Mocha Porter, Avery New World Porter, Bell's Porter, Great Divide S

EQUIPMENT.NAME: 6 Gal AG
EQUIPMENT.NOTES: 10 Gal. Pot with 10 Gal. Igloo Mash Tun

MASH_STEP.NAME: Step
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 2.86 gal of water at 143.2 F

MASH_STEP.NAME: Step
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 2.86 gal of water at 187.9 F

MASH_STEP.NAME: Step
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Decoct 1.47 gal of mash and boil it

RECIPE.NAME: All American Pale Ale v1

HOP.NAME: Centennial
HOP.NOTES: Use for: General purpose bittering, aroma in American ales and Wheats Aroma: Floral, citrus aroma, spicy, clean bittering flavor Substitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion Examples: Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale, Sierra Nevada Bigfoot

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Malt, Maris Otter
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Premium base malt from the UK. Popular for many English styles of beer including ales, pale ales and bitters.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Munich Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a reddish amber color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Victory Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Toasted malt that adds a "Biscuit" or toasted flavor to English ales. Use for: Nut brown ales, porters

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Honey Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Intensely sweet - adds a sweet malty flavor sometimes associated with honey. Also called Brumalt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Wheat Malt, Ger
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Malted wheat base for use in all wheat styles

YEAST.NAME: American Ale II
YEAST.NOTES: Clean, tart, nutty flavor. More fruity than Wyeast American Ale yeast.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: All American Ales, Brown Ales, Barley Wine

STYLE.NAME: American Pale Ale
STYLE.NOTES: http://www.bjcp.org/2008styles/style10.html#1a Refreshing and hoppy, yet with sufficient supporting malt. An American adaptation of English pale ale, reflecting indigenous ingredients (hops, malt, yeast, and water). Often lighter in color, cleaner in fermentation by-products, and having less caramel flavors than English counterparts
STYLE.PROFILE: There is some overlap in color between American pale ale and American amber ale. The American pale ale will generally be cleaner, have a less caramelly malt profile, less body, and often more finishing hops.
STYLE.INGREDIENTS: Pale ale malt, typ Am two-row. Am hops, often citrusy. Am ale yeast. Water can vary in sulfates, keep carbonates low. Specialty grains add character & complexity, make up a relatively sm portion of grist.
STYLE.EXAMPLES: Sierra Nevada Pale Ale, Stone Pale Ale, Great Lakes Burning River Pale Ale, Bear Republic XP Pale Ale, Anderson Valley Poleeko Gold Pale Ale, Deschutes Mirror Pond, Full Sail Pale Ale, Three Floyds X-Tra Pale Ale, Firestone Pale Ale, Left Hand Brewing Ja

EQUIPMENT.NAME: 6 Gal AG
EQUIPMENT.NOTES: 10 Gal. Pot with 10 Gal. Igloo Mash Tun

MASH.NAME: Single Infusion, Medium Body, Batch Sparge
MASH.NOTES: Simple single infusion mash for use with most modern well modified grains (about 95% of the time).

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash In
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 4.38 gal of water at 166.1 F

RECIPE.NOTES: forgot mash hops until last 30 minutes :(

HOP.NAME: Fuggles
HOP.NOTES: Used For: General purpose hops for bittering/finishing all British Ales Aroma: Floral, aromatic, earthy, slightly sweet spicy flavor Substitutes: Fuggles, BC Goldings Examples: Bass Pale Ale, Fullers ESB, Samual Smith's Pale Ale

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Malt, Maris Otter
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Premium base malt from the UK. Popular for many English styles of beer including ales, pale ales and bitters.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Smoked Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Malt that has been smoked over an open fire. Creates a distinctive "smoked" flavor and aroma. Used primarily for German Rauchbier but can also be added to Brown Ales and Porters.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 60L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt -120L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt. Very Dark

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Chocolate Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Black (Patent) Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Dark color and dry roasted flavor characteristic of Stouts and Porters Use for: Coloring in small amounts, or flavoring of Stouts and Porters in larger amounts.

YEAST.NAME: London ESB Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Malty, balanced flavor. Fruity, rich finish. Excellent for cask conditioned ales and bitters.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: English Bitters, IPA, Brown Ales, Mild Ales

STYLE.NAME: Mild
STYLE.NOTES: http://www.bjcp.org/2008styles/style11.html#1a A light-flavored, malt-accented beer that is readily suited to drinking in quantity. Refreshing, yet flavorful. Some versions may seem like lower gravity brown porters. May have evolved as one of the elements of early porters. In modern terms, the name "mild" refers to the relative lack of hop bitterness.
STYLE.PROFILE: Most are low-gravity session beers in the range 3.1-3.8%, although some versions may be made in the stronger (4%+) range for export, festivals, seasonal and/or special occasions. Generally served on cask; session-strength bottled versions don't often travel well. A wide range of interpretations are possible
STYLE.INGREDIENTS: Pale English base malts (often fairly dextrinous), crystal and darker malts should comprise the grist. May use sugar adjuncts. English hop varieties would be most suitable, though their character is muted. Characterful English ale yeast.
STYLE.EXAMPLES: Moorhouse Black Cat, Gale's Festival Mild, Theakston Traditional Mild, Highgate Mild, Sainsbury Mild, Brain's Dark, Banks's Mild, Coach House Gunpowder Strong Mild, Woodforde's Mardler's Mild, Greene King XX Mild, Motor City Brewing Ghettoblaster

EQUIPMENT.NAME: 6 Gal AG
EQUIPMENT.NOTES: 10 Gal. Pot with 10 Gal. Igloo Mash Tun

MASH.NAME: James' Standard Mash
MASH.NOTES: Simple single infusion mash for use with most modern well modified grains (about 95% of the time).

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash In
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 3.07 gal of water at 167.9 F

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash Out
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 1.01 gal of water at 209.6 F

HOP.NAME: Horizon
HOP.NOTES: Good dual purpose hops derived from Nugget hops in Oregon (1970) Use for: All purpose Ales, Lagers Aroma: Pleasant, Hoppy Substitutions: Magnum or other high alpha hops

HOP.NAME: Centennial
HOP.NOTES: Use for: General purpose bittering, aroma in American ales and Wheats Aroma: Floral, citrus aroma, spicy, clean bittering flavor Substitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion Examples: Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale, Sierra Nevada Bigfoot

HOP.NAME: Cascade
HOP.NOTES: Use For: American ales and lagers Aroma: Strong spicy, floral, grapefriut character Substitutes: Centennial Examples: Sierra Nevade Pale Ale, Anchor Liberty Ale A hops with Northern Brewers Heritage

HOP.NAME: Cascade
HOP.NOTES: Use For: American ales and lagers Aroma: Strong spicy, floral, grapefriut character Substitutes: Centennial Examples: Sierra Nevade Pale Ale, Anchor Liberty Ale A hops with Northern Brewers Heritage

HOP.NAME: Centennial
HOP.NOTES: Use for: General purpose bittering, aroma in American ales and Wheats Aroma: Floral, citrus aroma, spicy, clean bittering flavor Substitutes: Galena, Eroica, Nugget, Bullion Examples: Sierra Nevada Celebration Ale, Sierra Nevada Bigfoot

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Malt, Maris Otter
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Premium base malt from the UK. Popular for many English styles of beer including ales, pale ales and bitters.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 10L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt - 40L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Munich Malt - 10L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Malty-sweet flavor characteristic and adds a slight orange color to the beer. Does not contribute signficantly to body or head retention. Use for: Bock, Porter, Marzen, Oktoberfest beers

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Pale Chocolate Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Dark malt that gives a rich red or brown color and nutty flavor. Use for: Brown ales, porters, some stouts Maintains some malty flavor, not as dark as roasted malt.

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Victory Malt
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Toasted malt that adds a "Biscuit" or toasted flavor to English ales. Use for: Nut brown ales, porters

FERMENTABLE.NAME: Caramel/Crystal Malt -120L
FERMENTABLE.NOTES: Adds body, color and improves head retention. Also called "Crystal" malt. Very Dark

YEAST.NAME: London ESB Ale
YEAST.NOTES: Malty, balanced flavor. Fruity, rich finish. Excellent for cask conditioned ales and bitters.
YEAST.BEST_FOR: English Bitters, IPA, Brown Ales, Mild Ales

STYLE.NAME: American Amber Ale
STYLE.NOTES: http://www.bjcp.org/2008styles/style10.html#1bLike an American pale ale with more body, more caramel richness, and a balance more towards malt than hops (although hop rates can be significant). Known simply as Red Ales in some regions, these beers were popularized in the hop-loving Northern California and the Pacific Northwest areas before spreading nationwide.
STYLE.PROFILE: Can overlap in color with Am pale ales. However, Am amber ales differ from Am pale ales not only by being usually darker in color, but also by having more caramel flavor, more body, & usually being balanced more evenly between malt and bitterness. Should not have a strong chocolate or roast character that might suggest an American brown ale (although small amounts OK
STYLE.INGREDIENTS: Pale ale malt, typ Am two-row. Medium to dark crystal malts. May contain specialty grains which add character and uniqueness. Am hops, often w citrusy flavors, are common but others may also be used. Water can vary in sulfate & carbonate content.
STYLE.EXAMPLES: North Coast Red Seal Ale, Tregs HopBack Amber Ale, Deschutes Cinder Cone Red, Pyramid Broken Rake, St. Rogue Red Ale, Anderson Valley Boont Amber Ale, Lagunitas Censored Ale, Avery Redpoint Ale, McNeill's Firehouse Amber Ale, Mendocino Red Tail Ale, Bel

EQUIPMENT.NAME: James All Grain v4 - 13 Gallon - 10 Gallon Mash Tun

MASH.NAME: Single Infusion, Light Body, No Mash Out
MASH.NOTES: Simple single infusion mash for use with most modern well modified grains (about 95% of the time).

MASH_STEP.NAME: Mash In
MASH_STEP.DESCRIPTION: Add 7.00 gal of water at 165.5 F
